page.title: 16GREAT AYTON LOCAL HISTORY
page.content: "Ayton" means a farm by a river. People have lived here since at least the Bronze Age. In the original Domesday Book the village was variously called Atum, Atun and Aton. At that time it had 3 manors and was a thriving agricultural community. The first church was built about 8OO AD. Niches in the pews were for anti-plague disinfectant. The cemetry was enlarged after the 1349 Black Death. The Skottowe family, after whom a housing estate is named, once owned the village. There was a weekly market in the 13th century. In the 18th century, many handloom weavers lived here, then Whinstone quarrymen came in the 19th century after which the "iron rush" led to a sudden increase in the housing area though Ayton is now a dormitory town for the Cleveland industrial area.
